planets.name: Mercury
planets.description: Mercury—the smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun—is only slightly larger than Earth's Moon. Mercury is the fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every 88 Earth days.

planets.name: Venus
planets.description: Venus spins slowly in the opposite direction from most planets. A thick atmosphere traps heat in a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in our solar system.

planets.name: Earth

items.name: Moon
items.description: The Moon is Earth’s only natural satellite and the fifth largest moon in the solar system.The Moon’s presence helps stabilize our planet’s wobble and moderate our climate.

planets.description: Earth—our home planet—is the only place we know of so far that’s inhabited by living things. It's also the only planet in our solar system with liquid water on the surface.
planets.namesake: VARIATION OF 'THE GROUND' IN MANY LANGUAGES

planets.name: Mars

items.name: Deimos
items.description: Named after the Roman god of dread, Deimos is the smaller of Mars' two moons.

items.name: Phobos
items.description: The larger moon of Mars, gouged and nearly shattered by a giant impact crater.

planets.description: Mars is a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere. There is strong evidence Mars was—billions of years ago—wetter and warmer, with a thicker atmosphere.

planets.name: Jupiter

items.name: Adrastea
items.description: Adrastea was discovered in July 1979 by the Voyager science team.

items.name: Aitne
items.description: Aitne is a member of the Carme group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and appearance and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Amalthea
items.description: Amalthea was discovered Sept. 9, 1892 by Edward Emerson Barnard.

items.name: Ananke
items.description: Ananke was discovered on Sept. 28, 1951 by Seth Barnes Nicholson on a photograph made with the 100-inch (2.5 m) Hooker telescope at the Mount Wilson Observatory in California.

items.name: Aoede
items.description: Aoede was discovered Feb. 8, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Jan T. Kleyna, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Henry H. Hsieh at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Arche
items.description: Arche is a member of the Carme group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and appearance and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Autonoe
items.description: Autonoe was discovered Dec. 10, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Callirrhoe
items.description: Callirrhoe was discovered Oct. 19, 1999 via the 36-inch telescope on Kitt Peak, in the course of observations by the Spacewatch program of the University of Arizona.

items.name: Callisto
items.description: Callisto is the most heavily cratered object in our solar system.

items.name: Carme
items.description: Carme was discovered on July 30, 1938 by Seth Barnes Nicholson with the 100-inch (2.5 m) Hooker telescope at the Mount Wilson Observatory in California.

items.name: Carpo
items.description: Carpo was discovered on Feb. 26, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard and others from the University of Hawaii's Institute for Astronomy using the 12-ft. (3.6-m) Canada-France-Hawaii telescope at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Chaldene
items.description: Chaldene was discovered Nov. 23, 2000 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yange R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at an observatory on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

items.name: Cyllene
items.description: Cyllene was discovered Feb. 9, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard and his team from the University of Hawaii at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Dia
items.description: With a prograde orbit and a radius of about 1.2 miles (2 km), Dia is among the smallest member of the Himalia group.

items.name: Eirene
items.description: Eirene was discovered in February 2003 by Scott Sander Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Elara
items.description: Elara was discovered on Jan. 5, 1905 by Charles Dillon Perrine in photographs taken with the Crossley 36-inch (0.9 meter) reflector of the Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton at the University of California, San Jose.

items.name: Erinome
items.description: Erinome was discovered on Nov. 23, 2000, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Ersa
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: Euanthe
items.description: Euanthe was discovered on Dec. 11, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Eukelade
items.description: Eukelade was discovered on Feb. 6, 2003, by Scott S. Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Eupheme
items.description: Eupheme was discovered Mar. 4, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Euporie
items.description: Euporie was discovered on Dec. 11, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Europa
items.description: Europa might be the best place to look for environments where life could exist.

items.name: Eurydome
items.description: Eurydome was discovered on Dec. 9, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Ganymede
items.description: Ganymede is the largest satellite in our solar system. It is larger than Mercury and Pluto, and three-quarters the size of Mars.

items.name: Harpalyke
items.description: Harpalyke was discovered Nov. 23, 2000 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Hegemone
items.description: Hegemone was discovered on Feb. 8, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Jan T. Kleyna, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Henry H. Hsieh at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Helike
items.description: Helike was discovered on Feb. 6, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Hermippe
items.description: Hermippe was discovered in Dec. 9, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Herse
items.description: Herse was discovered on Feb. 27, 2003 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, and Lynne Allen.

items.name: Himalia
items.description: Himalia was discovered on 3 December 1904 by Charles Dillon Perrine in photographs taken with the Crossley 36-inch (0.9 meter) reflector of the Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton at the University of California, San Jose.

items.name: Io
items.description: Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system.

items.name: Iocaste
items.description: Iocaste was discovered Nov. 23, 2000 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Isonoe
items.description: Isonoe was discovered Nov. 23, 2000, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Jupiter LI
items.description: This tiny moon is one of several discovered from Earth-based telescopes with improved search techniques.

items.name: Jupiter LII
items.description: This tiny moon is one of several discovered from Earth-based telescopes with improved search techniques.

items.name: Kale
items.description: Kale was discovered Dec. 9, 2001 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Kallichore
items.description: Kallichore is a member of the Carme group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and appearance and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Kalyke
items.description: Kalyke is a member of the Carme group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and appearance and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Kore
items.description: Kore is considered a member of the Pasiphae group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Leda
items.description: Leda was discovered on Sept. 14, 1974 by Charles Thomas Kowal on plates taken from Sept. 11 through 13, 1974 with the 122-cm Schmidt telescope at Mount Palomar.

items.name: Lysithea
items.description: Lysithea was discovered on July 6, 1938 by Seth Barnes Nicholson with the 100-inch (2.5 m) Hooker telescope at the Mount Wilson Observatory.

items.name: Megaclite
items.description: Megaclite is considered a member of the Pasiphae group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Metis
items.description: Metis was discovered in March 1979 by the Voyager science team.

items.name: Mneme
items.description: Mneme is a member of the Ananke group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Orthosie
items.description: Orthosie is a member of the Ananke group, a family of Jovian satellites which have similar orbits and are therefore thought to have a common origin.

items.name: Pandia
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: Pasiphae
items.description: Pasiphae was discovered on Jan. 27, 1908, by Philibert Jacques Melotte with the Greenwich Observatory's 30-inch Cassegrain telescope.

items.name: Pasithee
items.description: Pasithee was discovered on Dec. 11, 2001, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Philophrosyne
items.description: S/2003 J15 was discovered in April 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Praxidike
items.description: Praxidike was discovered on Nov. 23, 2000, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J10
items.description: S/2003 J10 was discovered in February 2003 by Scott Sander Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J12
items.description: S/2003 J12 was discovered between Feb. 6 and Mar. 7, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard and others from the University of Hawaii's Institute for Astronomy at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J16
items.description: S/2003 J16 was discovered in April 2003 by Brett J. Gladman at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J18
items.description: S/2003 J18 was discovered in April 2003 by Brett Joseph Gladman at the Mauna Kea Observatory, Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J19
items.description: S/2003 J19 was discovered in February 2003 by Brett J. Gladman at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J2
items.description: S/2003 J2 was discovered in February or March 2003 at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Jan T. Kleyna, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Henry H. Hsieh.

items.name: S/2003 J23
items.description: S/2003 J23 was discovered in 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J4
items.description: S/2003 J4 was discovered in 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Jan T. Kleyna, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Henry H. Hsieh at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2003 J9
items.description: S/2003 J9 was discovered in February 2003 by Scott Sander Sheppard Sheppard at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: S/2011 J1
items.description: Little is known about this new moon of Jupiter.

items.name: S/2011 J2
items.description: Little is known about this new moon of Jupiter besides its approximate orbit.

items.name: S/2016 J 1
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2016.

items.name: S/2016 J2 (Valetudo)
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in June 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J 1
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2016. The discovery announcement was made in July 2017.

items.name: S/2017 J2
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J3
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J5
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J6
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J7
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J8
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: S/2017 J9
items.description: This tiny moon of Jupiter was first spotted in 2017. The discovery announcement was made in July 2018.

items.name: Sinope
items.description: Sinope was discovered on July 21, 1914, by Seth Barnes Nicholson on photographic plates taken with the Lick Observatory's 36-inch (0.9 meter) telescope.

items.name: Sponde
items.description: Sponde was discovered Dec. 9, 2001, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Taygete
items.description: Taygete was discovered Nov. 25, 2000, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, Yanga R. Fernandez, and Eugene Magnier at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Thebe
items.description: Thebe was discovered in 1980 by the Voyager science team from images taken by Voyager 1.

items.name: Thelxinoe
items.description: Thelxinoe was discovered on Feb. 9, 2003, by Scott S. Sheppard and Brett J. Gladman at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

items.name: Themisto
items.description: Themisto was initially discovered on Sept. 30, 1975, by Charles Thomas Kowal and Elizabeth Roemer.

items.name: Thyone
items.description: Thyone was discovered on Dec. 11, 2001, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna at the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.

planets.description: Jupiter is more than twice as massive than the other planets of our solar system combined. The giant planet's Great Red spot is a centuries-old storm bigger than Earth.

planets.name: Saturn

items.name: Aegaeon
items.description: Scientists imaged the moonlet on Aug. 15, 2008, and then confirmed its presence by finding it in two earlier images.

items.name: Aegir
items.description: Aegir was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004 (one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day) by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt, and Jan T. Kleyna using a wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.2-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Albiorix
items.description: Albiorix was discovered on Nov. 9, 2000 by Matthew J. Holman and Timothy B. Spahr, using the 6.5-m reflector telescope at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory on Mt. Hopkins, near Amado, Ariz.

items.name: Anthe
items.description: The Cassini Imaging team discovered Anthe on May 30, 2007, although a check back revealed Anthe in Cassini images as early as June 2004.

items.name: Atlas
items.description: Atlas was discovered in 1980 by R. Terrile and the Voyager 1 team from photographs taken during its encounter with Saturn.

items.name: Bebhionn
items.description: Bebhionn was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, and Jan T. Kleyna, using the wide-field camera on the 8.2-m Subaru telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, with orbital elements computed by Brian Marsden.

items.name: Bergelmir
items.description: Bergelmir was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, and Jan T. Kleyna, using wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Bestla
items.description: Bestla was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt, and Jan T. Kleyna, using wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Calypso
items.description: Calypso was discovered by D. Pascu, P.K. Seidelmann, W. Baum, and D. Currie in March 1980 using a ground-based telescope.

items.name: Daphnis
items.description: Daphnis was discovered by the Cassini mission team on 1 May 2005.

items.name: Dione
items.description: Giovanni Cassini discovered Dione on March 21, 1684.

items.name: Enceladus
items.description: Enceladus is Saturn's sixth largest moon, but it's one of the most scientifically compelling bodies in our solar system.

items.name: Epimetheus
items.description: Audouin Dollfus observed a moon on Dec. 15, 1966, for which he proposed the name 'Janus.' On Dec. 18 of the same year, Richard Walker made a similar observation, now credited as the discovery of Epimetheus.

items.name: Erriapus
items.description: Erriapus was discovered on Sept. 23, 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns at the Mauna Kea Observatory on the island of Hawaii.

items.name: Farbauti
items.description: Farbauti was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, using wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Fenrir
items.description: Fenrir was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, using a wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.2-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Fornjot
items.description: Fornjot was discovered on Dec. 12 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, using a wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.2-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Greip
items.description: Greip was discovered on March 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna using the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Hati
items.description: Hati was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, using a wide-field camera on the Subaru 8.2-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Helene
items.description: Helene was discovered on March 1, 1980 during the Earth ring-plane crossing by J. Lecacheux and others.

items.name: Hyperion
items.description: William Lassell discovered Hyperion in 1848.

items.name: Hyrrokkin
items.description: Hyrrokkin was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna using the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Iapetus
items.description: Giovanni Cassini discovered Iapetus on Oct. 25, 1671. However, to astronomers Iapetus appeared only as a dot whose brightness varied from brighter to fainter over the course of an orbit around Saturn.

items.name: Ijiraq
items.description: Ijiraq was discovered on Sept. 23, 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Janus
items.description: Audouin Dollfus observed a moon on Dec. 15, 1966, for which he proposed the name 'Janus.'

items.name: Jarnsaxa
items.description: Jarnsaxa was discovered on March 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan Kleyna using the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Kari
items.description: Kari was discovered on March 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, based on data obtained with the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, during the months of January to April, 2006.

items.name: Kiviuq
items.description: Kiviuq was discovered on Aug. 7, 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns at the European Southern Observatory in La Silla, Chile.

items.name: Loge
items.description: Loge was discovered on March 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna using the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Methone
items.description: The Cassini Imaging Team discovered Methone on June 1, 2004.

items.name: Mimas
items.description: Mimas was discovered on Sept. 17, 1789 by English astronomer William Herschel, using his 40-foot reflector telescope.

items.name: Mundilfari
items.description: Mundilfari was discovered in 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns using the 3.6-m Canada-France-Hawaii reflector on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

items.name: Narvi
items.description: Narvi was discovered on April 8, 2003 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna, from photos taken from Feb. 5 to 3 April 3.

items.name: Paaliaq
items.description: Paaliaq was discovered on Aug. 7, 2000, by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns at the European Southern Observatory in La Silla, Chile.

items.name: Pallene
items.description: The Cassini imaging team discovered Pallene on June 1, 2004.

items.name: Pan
items.description: Pan was discovered by M.R. Showalter in 1990 using images taken by the Voyager 2 spacecraft nine years earlier.

items.name: Pandora
items.description: Pandora, a potato-shaped moon, is coated in a fine (dust-sized) icy material. Even the craters on Pandora are coated in debris.

items.name: Phoebe
items.description: Phoebe was discovered August 1898 by American astronomer William Pickering.

items.name: Polydeuces
items.description: Polydeuces was discovered by the Cassini mission team on Oct. 21, 2004, and upon further review of Cassini images, scientists found it in images from April 9 of the same year.

items.name: Prometheus
items.description: The Voyager 1 science team discovered Prometheus in October 1980.

items.name: Rhea
items.description: Giovanni Cassini discovered Rhea on Dec. 23, 1672.

items.name: S/2004 S12
items.description: S/2004 S12 was discovered on 12 Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2004 S13
items.description: S/2004 S13 was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2004 S17
items.description: S/2004 S17 was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2004 S20
items.description: One of 20 new Saturn moons announced on Oct. 7, 2019.

items.name: S/2004 S7
items.description: S/2004 S7 was discovered on Dec. 12, 2004, one of 12 Saturnian moons found that day by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.description: One of 20 new Saturn moons announced on Oct. 7, 2019.

items.name: S/2006 S1
items.description: S/2006 S1 was discovered on Mar. 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2006 S3
items.description: S/2006 S3 was discovered on Mar. 6, 2006 by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2007 S2
items.description: S/2007 S2 was discovered in 2007 by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2007 S3
items.description: S/2007 S3 was discovered in 2007 by Scott S. Sheppard, David L. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: S/2009 S1
items.description: This new moonlet, situated about 300 miles (480 kilometers), inward from the outer edge of the B ring, was found by detection of its shadow which stretches 25 miles, or 41 kilometers, across the rings.

items.name: Siarnaq
items.description: Siarnaq was discovered on Sept. 23, 2000, by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Skathi
items.description: Skathi was discovered on Sept. 23, 2000, by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Skoll
items.description: Skoll was discovered on March 6, 2006, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: Surtur
items.description: Surtur was discovered on March 6, 2006, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna using the Subaru 8.3-m reflector telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

items.name: Suttungr
items.description: Suttungr was discovered in 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Tarqeq
items.description: Tarqeq was discovered on Jan. 16, 2007, by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna.

items.name: Tarvos
items.description: Tarvos was discovered on Sept. 23, 2000, by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Telesto
items.description: Telesto was discovered in 1980 using ground-based observations by Brad Smith, Harold Reitsema, Stephen Larson, and John Fountain.

items.name: Tethys
items.description: Giovanni Cassini discovered Tethys on March 21, 1684.

items.name: Thrymr
items.description: Thrymr was discovered in 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

items.name: Titan
items.description: Saturn’s largest moon, Titan has an earthlike cycle of liquids flowing across its surface.

items.name: Ymir
items.description: Ymir was discovered in 2000 by Brett J. Gladman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, Hans Scholl, Matthew J. Holman, Brian G. Marsden, Phillip D. Nicholson, and Joseph A. Burns.

planets.description: Adorned with a dazzling, complex system of icy rings, Saturn is unique in our solar system. The other giant planets have rings, but none are as spectacular as Saturn's.

planets.name: Uranus

items.name: Ariel
items.description: Ariel was discovered Oct. 24, 1851 by William Lassell, one of 19th century England's grand amateur astronomers, who used the fortune he made in the brewery business to finance his telescopes.

items.name: Belinda
items.description: Belinda was discovered on Jan. 13, 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Bianca
items.description: Bianca was discovered Jan. 23, 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Caliban
items.description: Caliban was discovered on Sept. 6, 1997 at Palomar Observatory by B. Gladman, P. Nicholson, J. A. Burns, and J. Kavelaars.

items.name: Cordelia
items.description: Cordelia was discovered on Jan. 20, 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Cressida
items.description: Cressida was discovered on Jan. 9, 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Cupid
items.description: Cupid was discovered on Aug. 25, 2003 by M.R. Showalter and J.J. Lissauer, using the Hubble Space Telescope.

items.name: Desdemona
items.description: Desdemona was discovered on Jan. 13 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Ferdinand
items.description: Ferdinand was discovered on Aug, 13, 2001 by Dan Milisavljevic, Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, and Tommy Grav, at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory.

items.name: Francisco
items.description: Francisco was discovered on Aug. 13, 2001 at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory by John J. Kavalaars, Matthew J. Holman, Dan Milisavljevic, and Tommy Grav.

items.name: Juliet
items.description: Juliet was discovered on Jan. 3, 1986 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Mab
items.description: Mab was discovered on Aug. 23, 2003 by Mark R. Showalter and Jack J. Lissauer, using the Hubble Space Telescope.

items.name: Margaret
items.description: Margaret is considered an irregular moon of Uranus because of the eccentricity and inclination of its orbit, but it is the only such moon that travels in a prograde direction.

items.name: Miranda
items.description: Miranda was discovered in telescopic photos of the Uranian system by Gerard P. Kuiper on Feb. 16, 1948 at the McDonald Observatory in western Texas.

items.name: Oberon
items.description: Oberon was discovered in Jan. 11, 1787 by William Herschel.

items.name: Ophelia
items.description: Ophelia was discovered in January 1986 in images sent back by the Voyager 2 spacecraft during its flyby of Uranus.

items.name: Perdita
items.description: Perdita was discovered 13 years after its picture was taken by Voyager 2 during the spacecraft's flyby in 1986.

items.name: Portia
items.description: Portia was discovered January 1986 in images sent back by the Voyager 2 spacecraft during its flyby of Uranus.

items.name: Prospero
items.description: Prospero was discovered July 18, 1999 by Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Brett J. Gladman, Jean-Marc Petit, and Hans Scholl using the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope at the Mauna Kea Observatory on the island of Hawaii.

items.name: Puck
items.description: Puck was discovered December 1985 in images sent back by the Voyager 2 spacecraft during its flyby of Uranus.

items.name: Rosalind
items.description: Rosalind was discovered by the Voyager 2 science team on 13 January 1986.

items.name: Setebos
items.description: Setebos is a small (about 48 km in diameter, assuming an albedo of 0.04), dark moon which orbits Uranus in the opposite direction from the regular moons and the planet's rotation (known as a retrograde orbit).

items.name: Stephano
items.description: Stephano was discovered on July 18, 1999 by Brett Gladman, Matthew Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Jean-Marc Petit, and Hans Scholl using the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope at the Mauna Kea Observatory on the island of Hawaii.

items.name: Sycorax
items.description: Sycorax was discovered on Sept. 6, 1997 by Philip D. Nicholson, Brett J. Gladman, Joseph A. Burns and John J. Kavelaars using the 200-inch Hale Telescope at Palomar Observatory.

items.name: Titania
items.description: Titania was discovered on Jan. 11, 1787 by British astronomer William Herschel.

items.name: Trinculo
items.description: Trinculo was discovered on Aug. 13, 2001 by Matthew Holman, John J. Kavelaars and Dan Milisavljevic at the Dominion Astrophysical Observatory in Victoria, British Columbia, and by using the 4-m reflector at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory.

items.name: Umbriel
items.description: Umbriel was discovered on Oct. 24, 1851 by English astronomer William Lassell.

planets.description: Uranus—seventh planet from the Sun—rotates at a nearly 90-degree angle from the plane of its orbit. This unique tilt makes Uranus appear to spin on its side.

planets.name: Neptune

items.name: Despina
items.description: Despina was discovered in July 1989 by the Voyager 2 science team.

items.name: Galatea
items.description: Galatea was discovered in July 1989 by the Voyager 2 science team.

items.name: Halimede
items.description: Halimede was discovered Aug. 14, 2002 by Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Tommy Grav, Wesley C. Fraser, and Dan Milisavljevic.

items.name: Hippocamp
items.description: Tiny Hippocamp may be a piece of larger Neptune moon Proteus.

items.name: Laomedeia
items.description: Laomedeia was discovered Aug. 13, 2002 by Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Tommy Grav, Wesley C. Fraser, and Dan Milisavljevic.

items.name: Larissa
items.description: Although it was initially spotted by H. Reitsema, W. Hubbard, L. Lebofsky, and D. Tholen through ground-based telescopes in 1981, Larissa was officially discovered in July 1989 by the Voyager 2 science team.

items.name: Naiad
items.description: Naiad was the last moon to be discovered during the Voyager 2 flyby in September 1989.

items.name: Nereid
items.description: Nereid was discovered on May 1, 1949 by Gerard P. Kuiper with a ground-based telescope.

items.name: Neso
items.description: Neso was discovered in 2002 by Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Tommy Grav, Wesley C. Fraser, and Dan Milisavljevic using the 4-m Blanco telescope at Cerro Tololo Observatory in Chile.

items.name: Proteus
items.description: Proteus was discovered in 1989 by the Voyager 2 spacecraft.

items.name: Psamathe
items.description: Psamathe was discovered by Scott S. Sheppard, David C. Jewitt and Jan T. Kleyna Aug. 29, 2003 using the 8.3-m Subaru reflector at the Mauna Kea Observatory on the island of Hawaii.

items.name: Sao
items.description: Sao was discovered Aug. 14, 2002 by Tommy Grav, Matthew J. Holman, John J. Kavelaars, Wesley C. Fraser, and Dan Milisavljevic.

items.name: Thalassa
items.description: Thalassa was discovered in August 1989 in images taken by Voyager 2.

items.name: Triton
items.description: Triton is the only known satellite in our solar system to have a surface made mainly of nitrogen ice.

planets.description: Neptune—the eighth and most distant major planet orbiting our Sun—is dark, cold and whipped by supersonic winds. It was the first planet located through mathematical calculations, rather than by telescope.

stars.name: Sun
stars.description: The Sun is a yellow dwarf star, a hot ball of glowing gases at the heart of our solar system. Its gravity holds everything from the biggest planets to tiny debris in its orbit.

moons.name: Moon
moons.description: Earth's Moon is the only place beyond Earth where humans have set foot, so far. The Moon makes our planet more livable by moderating how much it wobbles on its axis.

moons.name: Deimos
moons.description: Deimos—the smaller Martian moon—whips around Mars every 30 hours. Deimos is a dark body that appears to be composed of materials similar asteroids found in the outer asteroid belt.

moons.name: Phobos
moons.description: Phobos, gouged and nearly shattered by a giant impact crater, is on a collision course with Mars. The small moon will either crash into Mars in 50 million years or break up into a ring.

moons.name: Callisto
moons.description: Callisto is among the most heavily cratered objects that orbit the Sun. It is thought to be a long-dead world, with hardly any geologic activity on its surface—among the oldest landscapes in our solar system.
moons.namesake: Woman Changed into Bear by Roman Gods

moons.name: Ganymede
moons.description: Ganymede is the largest moon in our solar system and the only moon known to create its own magnetic field. Scientists have also found strong evidence of an underground ocean on Ganymede.

moons.name: Europa
moons.description: Europa is perhaps the most promising place to look for present-day environments suitable for life. Europa is thought to have an ocean of salty water below its frozen outer shell of ice.
moons.namesake: Woman abducted by greek god Zeus

moons.name: Io
moons.description: Io is the most volcanically active world in the solar system, with hundreds of volcanoes, some erupting lava fountains dozens of miles high. Io is caught in a tug-of-war between Jupiter and neighboring moons.
moons.namesake: Woman changed into cow by roman gods

moons.name: Iapetus
moons.description: Iapetus has been called the yin and yang of the Saturn moons because its leading hemisphere is dark as coal and its trailing hemisphere is much brighter.

moons.name: Titan
moons.description: Titan is bigger than Earth's moon, and even larger than the planet Mercury. Titan is the only moon in our solar system that has clouds and a dense atmosphere, and the only world apart from Earth with liquids on its surface.

moons.name: Rhea
moons.description: Rhea is the second largest moon of Saturn. Rhea has a thin atmosphere―called an exosphere―and is the first place a spacecraft foundtraces of oxygen in an atmosphere beyond Earth.

moons.name: Dione
moons.description: Dione orbits Saturn at about the same distance Earth's Moon orbits our home planet. The little moon is constantly bombarded by ice powder from Enceladus.

moons.name: Tethys
moons.description: Tethys is Saturn's fifth largest moon. Cold, airless and heavily battered, it has fewer impact craters than Dione and Rhea. It may have retained a molten surface longer than its sister moons.

moons.name: Enceladus
moons.description: Enceladus has a global ocean of salty water beneath its frozen shell of ice. It continually sprays this ocean into space from fissures near its south pole, creating Saturn's E ring as it orbits the giant planet.

moons.name: Mimas
moons.description: Crater-covered Mimas is the smallest and innermost of Saturn's major moons. Mimas is not quite big enough to hold a round shape and its low density suggests that it consists almost entirely of water ice.

moons.name: Oberon
moons.description: Oberon―the second largest moon of Uranus―is composed of roughly half ice and half rock. It has at least one large mountain that rises about 3.7 miles (6 kilometers) from the surface.

moons.name: Titania
moons.description: Titania—Uranus' largest moon—has a prominent system of fault valleys, some nearly 1,000 miles (1,609 kilometers) long. The troughs break the crust in two directions, a sign of past geologic activity.

moons.name: Umbriel
moons.description: Umbriel is the darkest of Uranus' largest moons. It reflects only 16 percent of the light that strikes its surface, a feature similar to the highland areas of Earth's moon.

moons.name: Ariel
moons.description: Ariel's surface appears to be among the youngest of all the Uranian moons. It has few large craters and many small ones, indicating low-impact collisions wiped out the large craters.

moons.name: Miranda
moons.description: Like Frankenstein's monster, Miranda looks like it was pieced together from parts that didn't quite merge properly. Miranda's giant fault canyons are as much as 12 times as deep as the Grand Canyon.

moons.name: Triton
moons.description: Triton―the largest of Neptune's moons―is the only large moon in our solar system to orbit in the opposite direction of its planet's rotation. It may be a captured Kuiper Belt Object.

astreoids.name: 101955 Bennu
astreoids.description: Bennu—discovered in 1999—is a small, near-Earth asteroid that passes close to Earth about every six years. Bennu is only slightly wider than New York City's Empire State Building is tall.

astreoids.name: 10199 Chariklo
astreoids.description: Chariklo was the first asteroid found to have a ring system. It was the fifth ring system found in our solar system - after Saturn, Jupiter, Uranus and Neptune.

astreoids.name: 2019 OK
astreoids.description: Near-Earth asteroid 2019 OK is a football-field-sized asteroid that safely passed close to Earth on July 24, 2019, with very little warning.

astreoids.name: 243 Ida
astreoids.description: Ida is the first asteroid found to have a moon.

astreoids.name: 25143 Itokawa
astreoids.description: In 2005, 25143 Itokawa became the first asteroid from which samples were captured and brought to Earth for analysis.

astreoids.name: 253 Mathilde
astreoids.description: Mathilde is an asteroid in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter,

astreoids.name: 433 Eros
astreoids.description: Eros was the first asteroid to be orbited by a spacecraft.

astreoids.name: 4 Vesta
astreoids.description: Vesta, the second most massive asteroid in the main belt.

astreoids.name: Apophis
astreoids.description: Asteroid 99942 Apophis is a near-Earth asteroid more than 1000 feet (over 300 meters) in size that will harmlessly pass close to Earth on April 13, 2029.

astreoids.name: Asteroid Psyche
astreoids.description: The asteroid was named after the nymph Psyche, who married Cupid but was put to death by Venus.

astreoids.name: Didymos
astreoids.description: Binary asteroid system Didymos is the target for NASA's DART mission - the agency's first planetary defense experiment.

Comets.name: 103P/Hartley (Hartley 2)
Comets.description: Hartley 2 was discovered by Malcolm Hartley on Mar. 15, 1986 using the Schmidt Telescope at the Siding Spring Observatory in Australia.

Comets.name: 109P/Swift-Tuttle
Comets.description: It takes comet Swift-Tuttle 133 years to orbit the sun once.

Comets.name: 19P/Borrelly
Comets.description: Resembling a chicken leg, the nucleus of comet 19P/Borrelly is small and measures approximately 2.98 miles (4.8 kilometers) in diameter.

Comets.name: 1P/Halley
Comets.description: Comet Halley is perhaps the most famous comet.

Comets.name: 21P/Giacobini-Zinner
Comets.description: It takes comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner 6.59 years to orbit the sun once.

Comets.name: 2I/Borisov
Comets.description: Comet 2I/Borisov is the first confirmed interstellar comet. It was discovered by Crimean amateur astronomer Gennady Borisov on Aug. 30, 2019, and quickly became a global phenomenon.

Comets.name: 2P/Encke
Comets.description: Comet 2P/Encke is a small comet. Its nucleus measures approximately 2.98 miles (4.8 kilometers) in diameter, which is about a third of the size of the object hypothesized to have led to the demise of the dinosaurs.

Comets.name: 55P/Tempel-Tuttle
Comets.description: It takes comet Tempel-Tuttle 33 years to orbit the sun once.

Comets.name: 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko
Comets.description: It takes comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko 6.5 years to orbit the sun once.

Comets.name: 81P/Wild (Wild 2)
Comets.description: 81P/Wild (Wild 2) is a small comet with the shape of a flattened sphere.

Comets.name: 9P/Tempel 1
Comets.description: Comet 9P/Tempel 1 orbits the sun within the asteroid belt, which lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. Tempel 1 last reached perihelion (closest approach to the sun) in 2016.

Comets.name: C/1861 G1 (Thatcher)
Comets.description: It takes 415 years for comet C/1861 G1 Thatcher to orbit the sun once.

Comets.name: C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)
Comets.description: Also called the Great Comet of 1997, comet C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp) is a large comet with a nucleus measuring approximately 37 miles (60 kilometers) in diameter.

Comets.name: C/2013 A1 Siding Spring
Comets.description: Comet C/2013 A1 Siding Spring is en route to buzz Mars in October 2014.

Comets.name: ISON
Comets.description: Comet ISON came from the Oort cloud region of our solar system.

Comets.name: Oumuamua
Comets.description: The first confirmed object from another star to visit our solar system.

Comets.name: P/Shoemaker-Levy 9
Comets.description: Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 was captured by the gravity of Jupiter, torn apart and then crashed into the giant planet in July 1994.

Meteors.name: January: Quadrantids
Meteors.description: The Quadrantids, which peak during early-January each year, are considered to be one of the best annual meteor showers.

Meteors.name: April: Lyrids
Meteors.description: The Lyrids, which peak during late April, are one of the oldest known meteor showers: Lyrids have been observed for 2,700 years.

Meteors.name: May: Eta Aquarids
Meteors.description: The Eta Aquarids peak during early-May each year. Eta Aquarid meteors are known for their speed.

Meteors.name: July: Southern Delta Aquariids
Meteors.description: The Southern Delta Aquariids are active beginning in mid-July and are visible until late August. These faint meteors are difficult to spot, and if the Moon is visible, you will not be able to view them.

Meteors.name: August: Perseids
Meteors.description: The Perseids, which peak during mid-August, are considered the best meteor shower of the year.

Meteors.name: October: Orionids
Meteors.description: The Orionids, which peak during mid-October each year, are considered to be one of the most beautiful showers of the year.

Meteors.name: November: Leonids
Meteors.description: The Leonids, which peak during mid-November each year, are considered to be a major shower though meteor rates are often as low as about 15 meteors per hour.

Meteors.name: December: Geminids
Meteors.description: The Geminids, which peak during mid-December each year, are considered to be one of the best and most reliable annual meteor showers.
